title: Expose the network-socket API through mbed.h
body:
Currently this uses the same mechanism used by the rtos to conditionally include the network-socket API. Perhaps this should be builtin to the config system?

Note: this does require that the bug-compatible inclusion of mbed.h be removed to avoid include-order issues, this may cause issues with existing examples. I will look into how this impacts mbed-os-example-client.

cc @sg-

title: Issue when using compile after building from IAR Workbench
body:
When trying to compile an example using `mbed compile -m NUCLEO_F746ZG -t ARM`, errors occur due to the files in the `projectfiles/iar_NUCLEO_F746ZG` also being linked. This causes the compilation to fail.

Copy of ARMmbed/mbed-cli#317
# To reproduce error
- Have the project exported to IAR using `mbed export -m NUCLEO_F746ZG -i IAR`
- Build the project inside of IAR Workbench
- Try to compile the project again using the CLI with `mbed compile -m NUCLEO_F746ZG -t ARM`
- This causes the compilation to fail, but it will work if you delete the `projectfiles/` directory first
# Error Example

An example of the error that is produced is:

title: Very minimal text
body: At least it has links

title: Fixed irq handling in gpio_api.
using --source for header files
exporter listing improvements
body:
## Problem

It is very hard to figure out what exporters are supported by a single board in the mbed-cli toolset.
#### Use case

I have a board plugged in, example code imported, and I want to export to a IDE to debug. I know the export command exists, but how do I know what exporters I can use? Currently I have to type `mbed export -i UVISION4 --supported` to get a list of all boards that uvision supports, but I dont want all boads, I just want to know about one board.
## Secondary Problem

The `mbed export -i ..... --supported` options overflows the standard windows window, even when I expand it to 2x its width, 160 characters, the lines still overflow, further the terminal is immediately line wrapped rendering the text garbled and meaningless, and worse yet I cant even see the top, i lose data and gain no knowledge from this other than frustration. 
## Solution

Here are some proposed solutions
1. enable `mbed export -m MCU --supported`, this would print a single line out of the matrix denoting what exporters the mcu supports
    \* extend this such that `mbed export --supported` takes the implicit target currently set 
2. clean up output of current tool so that it doesnt overflow or line wrap and is ledgible, current method is unusable
3. support tab completion, so i could `mbed export -i <tab>` and the list of supported IDE's for the current MCU would cycle, or even `mbed export -m MCU -i <tab>` for a similar effect. Adding tab completion negates the need for the massive table and enables the user to interactively explore the tool's options. 

Point is I cant easily figure out what exporters, need to fix this. 

@sg- @screamerbg

title: DNS failure when trying to get ip of local host
Include the EFM32GG_STK3700 in the release
body:
Set the mbed-os version 5 support flag for the EFM32GG_STK3700 so it
is tested and included in the upcoming release.

title: Heap and main thread stack checking
body: Turn on main thread stack checking. This PR is on top of #2319

title: Hexiwear fixups
body:
- add release to target.json
- add to mbed 2 RTOS tests

title: Increasing the heap for KL46Z for IAR.
body:
The KL46Z passes all tests on all toolchains except the following when built with IAR: `tests-mbedmicro-rtos-mbed-threads`.

This is because the heap is becomes fully allocated. This commit increases the heap from 8K to 16K.

Please review @c1728p9 
FYI @sg-

title: Adding docs for the testing process for mbed OS 5
body:
This adds documentation describing how tests are built and ran within mbed OS 5.
This doesn't cover the mbed CLI commands, but rather the underlying build and test runner process that's occurring when making the calls to mbed CLI and the underlying scripts.

It also describes how to debug tests with IDEs in conjunction with the test tools.

Please review @iriark01 
FYI @mazimkhan @adbridge

title: Mark VK_RZ_A1H as release target
body:
Mark VK_RZ_A1H as release target

depends on https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/2361 for FEATURE_IPV4
per https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/2361#issuecomment-237367533
cc @sg-

title: K64 HEXIWEAR: Add CTS and RTS pin defines
body: Signed-off-by: Mahadevan Mahesh Mahesh.Mahadevan@nxp.com

title: Enable FEATURE_IPV4 for the VK_RZ_A1H
body:
VK_RZ_A1H already has lwip support and restricting FEATURE_IPV4 is unnecessary.

should fix https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-client/issues/67
tested locally with [mbed-os-example-client](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-client) and the [nsapi tests](https://developer.mbed.org/teams/NetworkSocketAPI/code/NSAPITests/#0d938ec9100c)

cc @sg-, @bulislaw

title: Adding README for utest
body:
This README was pulled from the project's repo here: https://github.com/ARMmbed/utest.

I made minor modifications to the README to reflect the changes to the default scheduler (using a Timeout object instead of MINAR).

FYI @adbridge

title: Stack revert and null tid
body: Fix potential problems introduce by #2348.

title: [nsapi] Fix issue with reconnecting the ethernet interface
body:
Previously the EthernetInterface class was unable to be connected after being brought down. The core issue is that lwip was not designed to be completely brought down due once initialized.

To work around this, the ethernet interface only initializes once and leaves itself up after a disconnect call. The DHCP lease is still released/acquired on disconnect/connect.

This should fix #2334

Board: RZ_A1H
Version: mbed-os-5.1.0-rc4
OS: Linux/OSX
Toolchain: GCC and ARM

I've tried multiple examples, they compile just fine, but when I flash them, the board doesn't do anything. It seem that they are actually flashed (LED is blinking), then the board reboots, but it doesn't seem to be doing anything (depending on example e.g. no serial output or user led blinking), but the power LED is on and it flashes USB activity every now and again.
At the same time the HelloWorld_blinky.bin demo example on the board mbed page works fine (https://developer.mbed.org/platforms/VK-RZA1H/).

title: Intended project structure
body:
Hi there, 

We are doing our first attempt to port our current software to mbed5. The way we understood it, the new configuration would allow us to configure a new target per final product that could inherit from the platform target.

The initial idea was to translate all our old private yotta modules with different functionalities into "FEATURE_" folders. This way we could select the appropriate features for our different targets in the targets.json. Allowing us to fit everything (mbed5 + a bunch of own features) in one custom repository (reducing the overhead of maintaining and releasing).

For that approach to work, I had to modify the following code in /mbed-os/tools/config.py 

``` python
 # Allowed features in configurations
    __allowed_features = [
        "UVISOR", "BLE", "CLIENT", "IPV4", "IPV6", "COMMON_PAL", "STORAGE", "LOGGER"
    ]
```

Where "FEATURE_LOGGER" is just a dummy feature that I'm using to test this concept. The fact that I needed to do such change makes me think that this is not the intended way to add custom functionality to mbed5. What is then the intended project structure?

@MarceloSalazar @markus-becker-tridonic-com

title: Patch of #2318
body:
This PR is derived from #2318. This attempts to fix an issue that occurs in earlier version of Python when generating XML test reports.

The TCP and UDP echo test cases generate random ASCII sequences to be echoed back by the host PC. In the case where a test report needs to be generated, this causes the following error:

```
(UnicodeDecodeError) exporter_testcase_junit:'unicodeescape' codec can't decode bytes in position 5349-5350: truncated \uXXXX escape
```

This PR avoids this issue by limiting the range of random ASCII characters to just '0' - '9'. This should be sufficiently random but use safer characters that shouldn't cause issues when saving to XML files.

FYI @sg-

title: Fix intermittent Thread::join bug
body:
The function Thread::join determines if the thread the object it
represents has terminated by polling that threads TCB. This can
lead to problems since the RTOS frees the thread's TCB as soon as
the thread completes execution.

This patch updates the function Thread::join to use a semaphore to
determine when the thread finishes. This both avoids polling and
prevents a freed TCB from being accessed.

title: NUCLEO_F303RE (maybe others) SRAM wrong size in keil startup_*****.s
body:
Hi,
I often run out of memory when mallocating stuff, all the times i fixed the correct SRAM size (btw online compiler doesn't allow to edit the .s, needs to delete and import a fixed one), maybe it's time to open an issue:

https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/hal/targets/cmsis/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F3/TARGET_NUCLEO_F303RE/TOOLCHAIN_ARM_MICRO/startup_stm32f303xe.S#L54

https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/hal/targets/cmsis/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F3/TARGET_NUCLEO_F303RE/TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD/startup_stm32f303xe.S#L42

16KB size is for CCRAM, but it's mapped at 0x10000000 (probably not used at all in keil, not sure)
64KB is correct size for SRAM, mapped at 0x20000000

Don't know for other Nucleo targets, maybe worths a check.

title: Heap checking
body:
-Add checking so malloc actually returns 0 if it runs out of space for toolchains GCC_ARM and ARM. Toolchains IAR and uARM have a fixed size heap so this problem does not apply to them.
-Add a heap and stack test to make sure everything behaves as expected and to catch regressions.
-Turn on stack checking for all threads since heap and stack no longer overlap.
-Fix memory layout on KSDK2 causing heap and stack test to fail

title: [tools] Fixed infinite loop in config scan due to list comparison error
body:
Fixed infinite loop in config scan due to list comparison error.

Previously a scanning for config terminated on comparison of the feature set, however at some point the set was changed to a list. This resulted in non-deterministic failures based on list order.

Added a test specifically for the uvisor feature_add, which revealed the issue.

fixes https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/2312
cc @AlessandroA

title: NRF52_DK target publication
body: This is Nordic approval for release the NRF52_DK target and update of the NRF51_DK target.

title: export mbed-blinky to uvision4 and open it in uvison5, got compile error
body:
I used the command "mbed export -i uvision -m NRF51_DK"

Error message is:

linking...
..build\uvision4\Unnamed_Project.axf: error: L6002U: Could not open file ..build\uvision4\softdevice_handler_appsh.o: No such file or directory

title: [tools] Never-ending config_and_overrides scan
body:
Commit f3c0ea3664fea45233413ebabe29575b778f55aa introduced a regression in the build tools so that an app specifying `target_overrides` causes a never-ending scan of configs and overrides.

``` text
Building project mbed-os-example-uvisor (K64F, GCC_ARM)
Scan: .
Scan: FEATURE_BLE
Scan: FEATURE_CLIENT
Scan: FEATURE_COMMON_PAL
Scan: FEATURE_UVISOR
Scan: FEATURE_IPV4
Scan: FEATURE_IPV6
Scan: FEATURE_STORAGE
Scan: mbed
Scan: env
(hangs here)
```

To reproduce:

``` bash
$ mbed import https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-uvisor
$ cd mbed-os-example-uvisor/mbed-os
$ git checkout f3c0ea3664fea45233413ebabe29575b778f55aa
$ cd ..
$ mbed compile -m K64F -t GCC_ARM
```

You can look at the `mbed_app.json` file to see what was defined there:

``` json
{
    "target_overrides": {
        "K64F": {
            "target.features_add": ["UVISOR"],
            "target.extra_labels_add": ["UVISOR_SUPPORTED"]
        }
    }
}
```

If you checkout the previous commit the problem does not show up:

``` bash
$ cd mbed-os
$ mbed checkout f3c0ea3664fea45233413ebabe29575b778f55aa~1
$ cd ..
$ mbed compile -m K64F -t GCC_ARM
```

@geky @0xc0170

title: libstdc++ locale-inst.o
body:
Note: ticket originally raised here: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/484
### Description
- Type: Question
- Priority: Blocker
## Question

**What pulls in locale-inst.o and wlocale-inst.o?**

When investigating, why mbedOS is so big ROM-wise; i modified memap.py to show deeper into the directory structure which components are big. This led to the following output:

```
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------+--------+-------+-------+
| Module                                                                    |  .text | .data |  .bss |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------+--------+-------+-------+
...
| libstdc++.a(locale-inst.o)                                                |  39740 |     4 |    96 |
| libstdc++.a(wlocale-inst.o)                                               |  39689 |     4 |    96 |
...
```

What is pulling in 80k of locale support on an embedded device? Application is mbed-os-example-client.

@MarceloSalazar
@markus-becker-tridonic-com

title: Better RTOS integration for mbed-drivers
Project.py - does not accept -b ?
body:
Looks like a regression.  It used to be allowed to use `-b` : 

Currently:

```
python tools\project.py -m K22F -i iar -n MBED_10 -b
usage: project.py [-h] [-m MCU] [-i IDE] [-c] [-p PROGRAM] [-n PROGRAM]
                  [-b BUILD] [-L] [-S] [-E] [--source SOURCE_DIR] [-D MACROS]
project.py: error: argument -b: expected one argument
```

title: Fix clock selection used by the softdevice on NRF5 based targets.
body:
This patch fix the clock selection for the ble stack on NRF51_DK and NRF52_DK.
Without it, ble not work correctly on NRF52.

title: Print frendlier messages when auto-install fails and auto-install globally
Add missing --preinclude and -input on assembly files
body:
Except for IAR

Resolves #2272

title: Fix RTC test for LPC and STM families on GCC
body:
Remove the critical section in mbed_rtc_time.c and instead use a
mutex to protect this. This function does not need to be interrupt
safe, just thread safe.

This fixes crashes on the GCC_ARM toolchain on the RTC test due to
trying to lock the GCC environment mutex while in a critical section.
Prior to this patch, this failure was likely to occur on STM and LPC
processor families.

title: Enable v5 release for NUCLEO_F429ZI and RZ_A1H
body:
The DISCO_F429ZI is enabled for the version 5 release, but the NUCLEO_F429ZI is not currently. This PR turns it on.

The RZ_A1H also satisfies the requirements for the version 5 release, so it is being enabled as well.

title: Enforcing 'standard' build for version 5 release
body:
This PR enforces that the `default_build` in a target's definition in `hal/targets.json` is set to `standard` to be included in the version 5 release.

This is being enforced because `small` builds do not support multi-threading. This makes the capabilities more consistent across all boards in the version 5 release.

NOTE: This removes the MOTE_L152RC and the LPC11U68
from the version 5 release list because the 'default_build' for these
targets is currently set to 'small'.

title: mbed detect doesn't work on Mac OoB RC#1
body:
Version: https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/releases/tag/mbed-os-5.1.0-rc1
Target: K64F/Giant Gecko/Pearl Gecko/NUCLEO_L476RG/nRF51_DK
Host OS: Mac

mbed can't detect connected boards making `mbed test` fail

```
$ mbed detect 
[mbed] No mbed targets where detected on your system.
```

title: [HAL] Modified SPI to use shared mutex
body: Modified the `SPI` class to use a shared mutex for all instances in response to #2276. This is consistent with `I2C` and others.

title: Creating the doxygen front page
body: I don't have a good text for it yet - I just want to make sure it works properly on docs.mbed

title: nrf51 - document the legacy mcu support vs the new one?
body:
There are currently two nrf5x HAL, and it's not documented anywhere. For users to use or bugfix, we should provide a documentation reference to explain.

I assume the old one is "legacy" and might be removed once all the rest is ported to the new one.

Folder reference: https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/tree/master/hal/targets/cmsis/TARGET_NORDIC/

cc @pan-

title: Migration documentation minar -> threads
body:
Note: This is just a template, so feel free to use/remove the unnecessary things
### Description
- Type:  Question
- Priority:  Minor
## Question

Where do I find the documentation on how to move from minar events to RTOS threads?

Re-opened from https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/445#issuecomment-235424621.

@MarceloSalazar

title: [NRF51_DK] us_ticker.c doesn't support IAR build (rc1 oob)
body:
The RTC1_IRQHandler in us_ticker.c is implemented by inline assembler and there is no IAR toolchain support.  Detected by RC1 OOB test.

```
C:\Users\toywat01\Documents\GitHub\mbed-os-example-blinky>mbed compile -m NRF51_DK -t IAR
Building project mbed-os-example-blinky (NRF51_DK, IAR)
Scan: .
Scan: FEATURE_BLE
Scan: FEATURE_UVISOR
Scan: FEATURE_IPV4
Scan: mbed
Scan: env
Compile: rt_MemBox.c
Compile: rt_Memory.c
Compile: us_ticker.c
[ERROR]
  #error Compiler not supported.
   ^
"C:\Users\toywat01\Documents\GitHub\mbed-os-example-blinky\mbed-os\hal\targets\hal\TARGET_NORDIC\TARGET_MCU_NRF51822\us_ticker.c",382  Fatal error[Pe035]: #error directive: Compiler not supported.
Fatal error detected, aborting.

```

https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/hal/targets/hal/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_MCU_NRF51822/us_ticker.c#L382

title: Enable release of mbed os 5 for NRF based targets with at least 32K of RAM.
body:
The targets `DELTA_DFCM_NNN40`, `NRF51_DONGLE` and `TY51822R3` have enough RAM (32K) to have the RTOS enabled by default.

This PR enable the release of those targets for mbed os 5.

title: [tools] Fix precedence issue in cumulative attribute set-arithmetic
body:
Basically this:

```
a | b - c  !=  (a | b) - c
```

Prevented cumulative overrides from being correctly removed.

cc @screamerbg

title: Change default_build from small to standard on NRF based targets with at least 32K of RAM.
body:
NRF targets with 16K of RAM keep their default_build configuration set to small.
Enabling standard build consume 5K of RAM which is huge on a platform with only 6K of RAM usable.

This PR is a follow up to #2258
